This includes the library services, health and counseling and the use of sporting facilities.,DUELI can help prepare you for entry to degree-level study at Deakin University and other tertiary institutions in Australia. DUELI also offers English language programs if you want to develop English skills for personal or professional development. DUELI courses are task-based so you can develop the English skills needed to achieve success.,DUELI is accredited by the National ELICOS Accreditation Scheme (NEAS) and is a member of University English Centres Australia and English Australia.,If you don’t meet the admission requirements for Deakin or need to supplement your previous studies, an MIBT diploma can help fast-track your studies.,Some MIBT diplomas are equivalent to the first year of a Deakin undergraduate degree and may mean you can enter straight in to second year. MIBT to Deakin may be your answer.,You can apply for a wide range of scholarships to help you pay your university fees. We also recognise high-achieving students with a wide range of academic excellence scholarships, prizes and awards.,Scholarships are for full-time, on-campus international students and are awarded on the basis of academic merit.,You must be eligible to apply for your selected program and be citizens of a country other than Australia or New Zealand. Additional eligibility requirements may apply for selected scholarships.

name: Georgia State University
textBelow: Georgia State University was founded in 1913. It has 62 fields of study with 250 programmes offered by six colleges. The economic impact of the university is estimated at $1.4 billion a year. In autumn 2010 it had about 31,500 postgraduates and undergraduates.

name: Griffith University
textBelow: Opening its architectural award-winning doors on 470 acres of sculpted Queensland bush at Nathan in 1975, Griffith, named after one of the architects of Australian federation, now has four additional campuses, more than 300 degree courses, 3,700 academics and more than 37,000 students.

name: Leibniz Universität Hannover
textBelow: The scholar Karl Karmarsch founded the university in 1831. It started with 64 students and today has 21,000 studying the natural sciences and engineering, the humanities and social sciences, law and economics.

name: Harbin Institute of Technology
textBelow: Set up in 1920 to train railway engineers after Harbin in the far north-east of China was linked to the Trans-Siberian Railway, HIT now boasts 18 research stations and is a member of the C9 League. Its main campus and two satellites feature 21 schools and departments offering 300 programmes. It has around 42,700 students and some 3,000 scholars.

name: Heriot-Watt University
textBelow: Founded in 1821, Heriot-Watt had the world's first Mechanics Institute. It has around 1,600 members of staff, including more than 440 academics. It offers more than 400 programmes through six academic schools and two postgraduate institutes.

name: University of Idaho
textBelow: The university opened its doors in October 1892, when it welcomed 40 students and one professor, John Edwin Ostrander. Theodore Roosevelt was the first US president to visit the campus in 1911 and planted the first tree in Presidential Grove. Today, the institution is home to nearly 12,000 students and around 1,300 staff.

name: Kansas State University
textBelow: Founded in 1863, Kansas State University was one of the US' first land-grant colleges. Its graduate school offers 65 master's and 45 doctoral programmes in multiple disciplines. Earl Woods, Kansas State alumnus and father of golfer Tiger Woods, was one of the first African-Americans to play college sports in the US.

name: University of Kent
textBelow: In 2004, a joint venture with four universities across the Channel created the first Franco-British higher education facility, the Reau Universitaire Transmanche (Cross-Channel Universities Network). The following year, Kent, set up in 1965, diversified its home base, establishing a second campus at Chatham Maritime, Medway. Forty per cent of its students study social sciences.

name: Hiroshima University
textBelow: Rising out of the ashes of the atomic bomb through the amalgamation of several pre-war schools in 1949, the phoenix is appropriately Hiroshima's symbol. Its three campuses house 11 faculties, 12 graduate schools and three research institutes, which cater for nearly 20,000 students served by around 1,800 scholars.

name: La Trobe University
textBelow: Named after Charles La Trobe, the first governor of the new colony of Victoria in 1851, the university opened its doors in 1967. Spread over seven campuses, 25,700 students are taught by 2,700 staff in five faculties: education; health sciences; humanities and social sciences; law and management; and science, technology and engineering.

name: Loughborough University
textBelow: Receiving its charter in 1966 as the Loughborough University of Technology, it began as a small technical institute founded in 1909. Renamed in 1996, its 437 acres now form one of the largest single-site campuses in the UK, with more than 16,000 students and over 1,000 academic staff divided into 18 departments.

name: Kobe University
textBelow: Located in the green foothills of Mount Rokko overlooking the port city, Kobe was founded in 1949. It added a medical school in 1964, agriculture in 1966 and mercantile marine studies in 2003. Today, it has more than 16,000 students and an academic staff of around 1,330 scholars.

name: Mahidol University
textBelow: With two faculties of medicine and four teaching hospitals, Mahidol's pedigree began with the setting up of Siriraj Hospital in 1888. Renamed in 1969, its three campuses and three regional satellites house a further 15 faculties, 16 colleges and seven research institutes. The university's 3,100 academic staff serve 26,500 students.

name: Massey University
textBelow: Named after New Zealand PM William Massey, the university began life as an agricultural college in 1928. Expansion brought university status in 1964 and later new campuses in Auckland and Wellington. More than 36,000 students are taught by around 1,100 staff in five colleges: business; creative arts; education; humanities and social sciences; and science.

name: Michigan Technological University
textBelow: Located in the heart of Copper County, once the greatest producer of the metal in the world, Michigan Tech started life in 1885 as a mining school. It achieved university status in 1964: today, its 925-acre campus accommodates some 7,000 students and a 445-strong faculty. It also has a 4,000-acre forestry research centre in Alberta.

name: National Central University
textBelow: NCU moved to its hilltop campus in Jhongli, 50 miles east of Taipei, in 1968, although its roots lie in early 20th-century Nanjing. It has 11,800 students and a full-time faculty of more than 740 in seven colleges: liberal arts; science; engineering; management; electrical engineering and computer science; earth sciences; and hakka studies.

name: Liverpool John Moores University
textBelow: Liverpool John Moores University can trace its origins back to 1825 and the foundation of the Liverpool Mechanics' School of Art. It gained university status in 1992 and now has four academic faculties on three main campuses, 24,000 students and around 2,800 academic staff.

name: New Jersey Institute of Technology
textBelow: Thomas Edison had a lab on Ward Street and Newark was already one of the US' industrial hubs when in 1881 it set up its technical school, which by 1975 had developed into NJIT. Its 45-acre campus has around 8,800 students and about 400 full-time scholars offering 44 bachelor's, 49 master's and 19 doctoral programmes.

name: National Taiwan Ocean University
textBelow: Established in 1953, the National Taiwan Ocean University in Keelung specialises in marine sciences and technology. It has a total of six colleges, comprising 15 departments and 12 graduate institutes. It had 646 staff and 8,542 students in 2010.

name: National University of Ireland, Maynooth
textBelow: After 200 years of education, Maynooth was granted full autonomy in 1997 as a member of the federal National University of Ireland. Today, it has 8,400 registered students across 26 academic departments and three faculties. It is the Republic of Ireland's fastest-growing university and recently benefited from a 100 million building programme. One of its alumni, Daniel Mannix, a former Maynooth president, later became Archbishop of Melbourne.

name: Old Dominion University
textBelow: ODU's 185-acre campus in Norfolk, Virginia (home to the world's largest naval base) and three satellites accommodate more than 24,000 students and offer 69 bachelor's, 55 master's, 41 doctoral and two educational specialist degrees. It achieved university status in 1969 after splitting from the College of William and Mary in nearby Williamsburg in 1962.

name: New University of Lisbon
textBelow: Founded in 1973, the New University of Lisbon is the youngest of Portugal's three state institutions. It has nine academic units - including science and technology, social sciences, economics and management, law, humanities, and life sciences and medicine (incorporating tropical and public health) - and more than 15,000 students.

name: National University of Ireland, Galway
textBelow: With strong connections to the Irish language, OGaillimh began life as Queen's College in 1845. Becoming a university college in 1907, it was renamed in 1997. Strong in internet-technology research, it has five colleges, 2,200 academics and 16,000 students.

name: Université Paris 13
textBelow: Université Paris 13 is one of the member universities of the Sorbonne Paris research higher education cluster. It has close to 22,000 students over four campuses. Its nine teaching units cover five main fields of study: human and social sciences; science, technologies and health; culture and communication; law, economics and management; and arts, literature and languages.

name: Kyung Hee University
textBelow: Unique to East Asia, Kyung Hee opened its peace institute on a dedicated 12-acre site in 1984. Founded as a college in 1949, it moved to its 245-acre Seoul campus as a private university in 1952, adding its 510-acre Global campus in 1979. Today, a faculty of some 3,140 educate a total student body of around 23,000.

name: Polytechnic University of Catalonia
textBelow: Specialising in architecture, science and engineering, UPC has the highest number of international PhD and master's students in the Spanish academy. It was founded in 1971.

name: Polytechnic University of Turin
textBelow: In 1859, a technical school for engineers was set up in the Castello del Valentino. Today, the 17th-century palace houses the architecture department of the Politecnico, founded in 1906, while engineers are housed at the Corso Duca degli Abruzzi campus. More than 28,000 students supervised by an academic staff of 900 can choose from 116 courses.

name: Pontifical Catholic University of Chile
textBelow: The Pontifical Catholic University of Chile was founded in 1888. It has 18 faculties on four campuses distributed throughout Santiago. It has around 2,800 faculty members, and 550 research projects are conducted there every year. It offers training in the humanities and in technological and applied fields such as business, accounting and chemistry.

name: Saint Petersburg State University
textBelow: SPBU's claim to be Russia's oldest university is disputed by Moscow State because it closed in 1803 and was refounded in 1819. What is not disputed is its later prestige: Vladimir Putin and his successor, Dmitry Medvedev, both studied law here. Ayn Rand was a history honours graduate in 1924. Today, 15,000 staff serve 39,000 students.

name: Polytechnic University of Valencia
textBelow: The Polytechnic University of Valencia was founded in 1971. It has 44 departments, nearly 37,800 students, 2,600 teaching and research staff, 1,700 administrative and services personnel, 10 schools and three faculties.

name: University of South Australia
textBelow: The University of South Australia is a globally focused, locally engaged institution established on the dual principles of equity and excellence. With more than 33,000 students the University offers a quality educational experience that is innovative, world-class and built on more than 150 years of teaching, learning and research excellence.,Almost 70 per cent of academic staff hold doctorates, which puts the University in the top 10 universities in Australia on this criterion. Teachers are experts in their fields and passionate about sharing their knowledge and a number of the teaching staff are recipients of prestigious local and national teaching awards.,Programs are designed in close consultation with industry and professional partners and include fieldwork, placements, industry-guided simulations and business projects. Students have the opportunity to take their skills beyond the lecture theatre and into the community to gain practical experience as part of their studies. This real-world interaction provides students with the qualities that employers look for as well as job-ready expertise when they begin their professional careers.,The University is a research leader with a reputation for excellence across a range of discipline areas. It is committed to high quality research that contributes practical solutions to real-world challenges and engages in cutting edge research through its recognised institutes and centres. The most recent national Excellence in Research for Australia (ERA) evaluation reported that 86 per cent of the University's assessed research was rated as world-class standard or above.,The University funds research activities that encourage individual researchers and also supports research in identified areas of strength in order to address national needs. Our six specialist research institutes are delivering innovative and fundamental advances in knowledge.,The University also has 17 research centres and is a key partner in 12 Cooperative Research Centres (CRCs) that bring together expertise and resources from other institutions, industry and government. Our research degree students work closely with the University’s institutes and centres, which ensures they maximise their opportunities and experience a vibrant research environment.,The University’s six campuses reflect the core commitments of environmental sustainability and regional engagement. World-class facilities make the University a great place to study with modern research facilities, state-of-the-art information technology, new flexible learning spaces and around-the-clock support through our online learning environment. The University is also investing more than AU$1 billion in new infrastructure to ensure students and staff have access to the very latest facilities and amenities.,The University offers a large range of academic, personal and social support services to help students realise their potential. There are dedicated offices and staff on each campus to answer questions and help make university life easier. Online support is also available 24/7, as well as support services to help students settle into campus life, excel in studies and make the most of university experiences.,The energy, talents and commitment of staff is vital to the University realising its academic, research and community aspirations. As a workplace, it is characterised by a strong sense of social purpose and shared pride in individual and collective efforts and achievements.,The University provides a challenging, varied and enriching work environment with a vibrant and supportive culture. Excellent employment benefits, professional development opportunities and services to support staff and their families are just a few of the benefits available to University,employees.,With a family-friendly approach promoting work life balance, you’ll feel right at home at the University of South Australia. Please visit: unisa.edu.au/workingatunisa for further information and to view our current vacancies.,Adelaide is the most affordable mainland Australian capital city for study, according to research from the Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU). In 2013, the Property Council of Australia ranked Adelaide as Australia's most liveable city for the third consecutive year. And in the EIU annual Global Liveability Survey, Adelaide was among the top ten places in the world to live.,With a population of just over one million people, the Adelaide community is a welcoming, accessible and truly multicultural place to live and study. The city is located between white sandy beaches and the Mount Lofty Ranges. Known as the '20 minute city', it takes no more than 20 minutes to travel from the city to the hills or beaches. Adelaide is also renowned for its world-class food, wine, hospitality and cultural life.

name: University of Strathclyde
textBelow: Born in 1796 of a bequest by John Anderson of the University of Glasgow, Strathclyde received its university charter in 1964. Since then it has grown from 4,000 full-time students in 1964 to 26,000, served by 3,200 staff, with another 34,000 students in continuing education and professional-development programmes. David Livingstone attended here, as did television pioneer John Logie Baird.

name: Swansea University
textBelow: Founded in 1920, Swansea University has more than 12,000 students and offers more than 500 undergraduate and 130 postgraduate courses. In recent years, the university has invested heavily in research and opened the Institute of Life Science in June 2007, a 50 million facility. Famous alumni include broadcaster Mavis Nicholson and members of the Manic Street Preachers.

name: Swinburne University of Technology
textBelow: George Swinburne, a businessman and civic leader, established the institution in Melbourne in 1908. It was first known as the Eastern Suburbs Technical College. It achieved university status in 1992 and has five campuses: Croydon, Hawthorn, Lilydale, Prahran and Wantirna, plus an overseas outpost in Sarawak, East Malaysia. It has more than 81,000 alumni worldwide.

name: University of Salento
textBelow: Salento was founded in 1956 and is located in the Apulia region of Italy - the "heel" of the Italian "boot". It was recognised as a national university in 1967-68. It now has three campuses, 10 faculties and 750 faculty members. It offers up to 40 first- and second-level master's and PhD programmes.

name: University of Tartu
textBelow: Tartu was founded in 1632 by Sweden's King Gustavus Adolphus. It is regarded as one of the most prestigious educational institutions in Central and Eastern Europe. It has nine faculties with more than 70 departments and institutions, and about 17,000 students. The university's hall of fame includes engineer and physicist Moritz Hermann Jacobi.

name: Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology
textBelow: The Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology was founded in May 1949 but its roots stretch back to 1874. In May 2010, it catered for 3,998 undergraduates and 1,954 postgraduates and employed 640 members of staff.

name: University of Turku
textBelow: Ninety years ago, in the first flush of independence, nationalists raised funds from 22,040 donors for a truly Finnish university in the nation's second city. Their generosity is commemorated in the university's own liquor creation (made of cloudberry, rowan and sea buckthorn), christened "22040". Its 18,000 students include 2,000 postgraduates.

name: Waseda University
textBelow: Founded by samurai scholar, pro-Western Meiji-era moderniser and later prime minister Okuma Shigenobu, Waseda made a big thing of its 125th anniversary in 2007 because of Shigenobu's theory that humans' "natural" lifespan is 125 years. Waseda's campus was destroyed during the Second World War, but it reopened in 1949. Today, some 6,000 faculty members serve more than 54,000 students.

name: University of Zaragoza
textBelow: The University of Zaragoza, in Spain's Ebro Valley, can trace its origins back to the Ecclesiastical Schools of the 7th century. It now has more than 3,500 teachers and nearly 1,800 researchers and administrative staff.

name: University of Wyoming
textBelow: The institution was established in Laramie in 1886. Its first president, John Wesley Hoyt, planned a curriculum focused on the arts and humanities. Today, it teaches 13,000 students. President John F. Kennedy addressed the campus in 1963, the year of his assassination.

name: University of Bath
textBelow: Bath's logo features the Gorgon's head, reminder of the city's Roman past, and melds Sul the Goddess of Hot Springs with Minerva, Goddess of Learning. More than a quarter of the approximately 14,000 students enrolled at the university, set up in 1966, are from outside the UK, particularly China, Germany and Greece.

name: Wuhan University
textBelow: Wuhan University was founded in 1893. It has approximately 5,000 teachers, 3,000 professors and 570 doctoral supervisors. More than 20 periodicals are published on campus. In 1993, representatives from Harvard, Tokyo and Yale universities attended its centennial celebrations.

name: Bangor University
textBelow: Bangor was established in 1884 as a direct result of a campaign for higher education provision in Wales. It began with 58 students and 10 members of staff teaching out of an old coaching inn. The university now has more than 12,000 students, 2,000 staff members, 23 academic schools and an annual turnover of 126 million. The film-maker Danny Boyle is a notable alumnus.

name: Universität Bielefeld
textBelow: Situated next to the Teutoburg Forest, the site of a resounding Roman military defeat at the hands of Germanic tribes in 9AD, Bielefeld itself is a relative newcomer to the German academic scene, opening its doors in 1969. It has more than 17,500 students, an academic staff of about 1,580 and 14 faculties.

name: Brunel University
textBelow: Named after Victorian engineer Isambard Kingdom Brunel, the institution was founded in 1928 as Acton Technical College. It became a university in 1966 and is now served by around 1,100 academic, professional and research staff across eight schools.

name: Yuan Ze University
textBelow: Established in 1989, Yuan Ze University labels itself the youngest and "most energetic" of Taiwan's top universities. Despite its youthfulness, Yuan Ze has been recognised as a benchmark for new universities - its motto is "Sincerity, Diligence, Thrift, Prudence". Boasting five faculties, it caters for more than 9,000 students, who can choose from more than 12,000 degree programmes. Its 330-plus full-time faculty members, 86 per cent of whom are educated to PhD level, contributed to it being the first Taiwanese university to win the National Quality Award in 2003.

name: University of Hawaii at Manoa
textBelow: Hawaii's Pacific Ocean position proves a powerful draw for students from East and West. It was founded in 1907 as a land-grant College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts, attaining university status in 1920. Its 10 campuses, distributed across the islands, offer 644 programmes to a student body of around 58,000.

name: Karl-Franzens-Universität Graz
textBelow: More than 70 years after one in six of its teaching staff, including three Nobel laureates, were expelled for their anti-Nazi views, the university is undergoing rapid growth. Here, Alfred Wegener developed his theory of continental drift. Today, the institution accommodates around 27,000 students and some 3,500 staff. Its newest faculty, the Faculty of Environmental and Regional Sciences and Education, opened in 2007.

name: Technische Universität Dresden
textBelow: Dresden is one of 11 German institutions identified by the federal government as an "excellence university". It has about 36,500 students and around 5,300 employees (including more than 500 professors). It is the largest university in Saxony and one of the largest in Germany. Having been committed to the sciences and engineering before the reunification of the country, it has now widened its curriculum, offering humanities, social science and medical courses.

name: Hong Kong Polytechnic University
textBelow: The Hong Kong Polytechnic University (PolyU) is committed to education and preparing students to becoming global citizens through quality learning and teaching.  We are internationally known for our excellence in innovative research and unique programmes.,Established in 1937, we have groomed over 330,000 graduates, many of whom have become leaders in their professional fields, contributing their knowledge and expertise to building Hong Kong's thriving economy., ,PolyU offers a wide range of programmes, from higher diplomas to doctoral degrees.  All our programmes are fully accredited with their key strengths being their practical application and professional relevance to the industries. Many of which are among the best in Asia, and indeed the world. ,Hong Kong is one of the most dynamic cities in the world.  Nevertheless, the city has something for everyone, from the most economical options to extreme extravagance. As a student, you can also enjoy a vast range of discounted offers, from transportation to different kinds of entertainment.,Tuition fee for a full-time Bachelor's Degree programme per academic year is approximately GBP8,900(HKD110,000). Scholarships up to approximately GBP12,200 (HKD150,000) are awarded to students with outstanding academic merits as well as those with other non-academic achievements.  ,All international students will be offered 3-years guaranteed accommodation at our Student Halls of Residence, which is just under 10-minute walking distance from the campus, at a monthly rental of approximately GBP100 (HKD1,240) for a shared room.,Hong Kong is such a compact place so getting around is extremely easy. Our well-developed public transportation network and bilingual signage ensure your quick, convenient and easy access to almost anywhere in the city. More importantly, PolyU is located right in the heart of Hong Kong so you could even get around in flip-flops and get anything you need in the neighborhood. ,Hong Kong presents an ever-changing kaleidoscope of culture and traditions.  As a gourmet paradise and shopper's heaven, the city offers a glittering array of local and international choices.  And if you yearn to escape to greener landscapes, numerous country parts and hiking trails offer "active relaxation" and spectacular views over Hong Kong's picturesque scenery!,Apart from academic studies, there are lots of activities for students to develop their different competencies and skills during term time. Just to mention a few, there are physical education courses that keep you healthy, language and leisure courses, professional development seminars and so on. All of which are non-credit bearing and free from assessment.  And most importantly, all these courses are either free of charge or just at a minimal amount of GBP4 (HKD50) per semester!,All international students will be offered 3-years guaranteed accommodation at our Student Halls of Residence, which is just under 10-minute walking distance from the campus, at a monthly rental of approximately GBP100 (HKD1,240) for a shared room.,You can truly immerse yourself into the lifestyle of a PolyU student by staying at the Student Halls of Residence. All rooms are fully furnished with a shared bathroom between two adjacent rooms. Each room is air-conditioned and equipped with broadband internet access.,Depending on your preference and budget, some of you might like to go for other forms of university-managed accommodation including private premises near the campus or arrange our own accommodation off-campus. Out Student Affairs Office can provide information to help you get started.  ,To apply for full-time studies, you will have to submit your application online a year in advance via our ,., ,In general, you will need to achieve an academic standard equivalent to GSC A-level or have satisfactorily completed the International Baccalaureate Diploma or your first year of university education.  ,You will also need to achieve a TOEFL score of 550, 213 or 80 for  internet-based test, or an overall band score of 6 in IELTS in terms of English language requirement. ,You should choose your desired programme from our ,  where you will also be able to find the entrance requirement of  theprogramme you are interested in. Your application could then be made directly online via our ,., ,Application for September 2014 entry shall commence around mid-September 2013.  For general enquiries, please email ,., ,

name: Christian-Albrechts-Universität zu Kiel
textBelow: Its founding mission, to replace civil-servant casualties from the Thirty Years' War, explains the motto adopted by Kiel when it was founded in 1665: "Pax optima rerum" ("Peace is the greatest good").

name: Ruhr-Universität Bochum
textBelow: When classes began in 1965, RUB was the first new public university in Germany since the Second World War. That same year, work began on its extensive botanical gardens, the highlight of which is the Chinese water garden that was built with the help of Shanghai's Tongji University. It has nearly 32,000 students and more than 2,800 academics.

name: Kyushu University
textBelow: Situated on the southernmost of Japan's larger islands, Kyushu's roots stretch back to an imperial medical and engineering foundation in 1903. "Imperial" was dropped from its title in 1947 and today its seven campuses are spread over 738 acres. It accommodates an academic staff of around 2,180 scholars and some 18,600 students in 54 schools, faculties and research institutes.

name: National Sun Yat-Sen University
textBelow: Set up in Kaohsiung, Taiwan's second-largest city and its major port, in 1980, NSYSU is a reinvention of an earlier namesake in Canton, founded in 1923. Today's university has more than 10,000 students in seven colleges: liberal arts; science; engineering; management; marine sciences; social sciences; and general education.

name: Queen's University Belfast
textBelow: Founded by Queen Victoria in 1845, just 90 students constituted the institution's first intake four years later. Queen’s, which gained its current name in 1908, has more than 17,000 and an academic staff operating from three faculties: arts, humanities and social sciences; medical, health and life sciences; and engineering and physical sciences.

name: Nanjing University
textBelow: As one of China's four ancient capitals, Nanjing's academic roots stretch back nearly 2,000 years, although today's university has its roots in a higher school set up on the site of an old imperial university in 1915. It gained its current name in 1952. Today it has more than 22,000 students taught by a staff of 3,000.

name: University of Southern Denmark
textBelow: French-born Princess Marie is patron of the University of Southern Denmark, which was founded in 1966. SDU's state-of-the-art research reputation is built on expertise in areas as diverse as biotechnology, stem-cell research, robotics, political science, management, literature and history. The institution is a comprehensive university with five faculties located in six cities. Some 2,200 staff teach around 20,000 students.

name: Stellenbosch University
textBelow: Recognised as one of the top four research institutions in South Africa, Stellenbosch was established in 1918, although its roots can be traced back to the 17th century. It has the country's highest proportion of postgraduates among its 24,000-strong student body, of whom 10 per cent are international. Stellenbosch's multicultural student body is one of its biggest strengths and its student organisations cater for a wide range of interests including culture, politics and religion. It has 800 lecturers and 50 research and service bodies. England batsman Jonathan Trott is a notable alumnus.

name: The University of Texas at Dallas
textBelow: Founded in 1969, The University of Texas at Dallas has evolved into one of the top research institutions in Texas, and its programs in engineering and the biomedical sciences have gained national attention. With an enrollment of 21,193, UT Dallas offers students the close-knit community of a small university with excellent student-faculty ratios of 22:1. However, UT Dallas is also backed by the powerful UT System and is aligned strategically with other institutions to offer advanced research opportunities traditionally found at larger institutions. ,About 64% of UTD pre-med students are admitted to medical schools, compared to an average national admission rate of 45%. In addition, 89% of students advised through the Pre-Law Advising and Resource Center were admitted to one or more law schools.,As a young, agile and rapidly growing university, The University of Texas at Dallas attracts a unique combination of student and faculty resources to the vibrant, dynamic and globally connected Dallas-Fort Worth area. UT Dallas is ranked in the top 100 by Kiplinger's and in the top 75 by The Princeton Review as a best value among public universities, and Times Higher Education ranks UT Dallas as #15 among the top 100 universities in the world under 50 years of age.,UT Dallas consistently draws a high caliber of student. The average entering freshman SAT for fall 2013 was 1261. Nearly 38% of freshmen ranked in the top 10% of their high school class, with 71% in the top 25%. UT Dallas is ranked among the top 100 American universities in the number of National Merit Scholars enrolled, and the University confers a higher percentage of science, engineering and business degrees (86%) than all other Texas public doctoral-granting institutions combined (59%).,UT Dallas is located in suburban Richardson, Texas, a prime location that places the University in the second largest state and the fourth largest metropolitan area in the nation. Because of the two local airports, Dallas Love Field and Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport, the Dallas area is an international destination. Richardson, known as The Telecom Corridor, is home to diverse global technology-based companies. ,The Dallas-Fort Worth Metroplex is one of the nation's largest urban areas, with shopping, entertainment venues, five major sports teams, museums and art galleries, and places for outdoor running, biking, hiking and skating. Area attractions include the Fort Worth Stockyards, the Dallas and Fort Worth zoos, Fair Park, the Dallas World Aquarium, the Perot Museum of Nature and Science, the Kimbell and Amon Carter museums and the Dallas Arts District. Major sports teams include the Dallas Cowboys and their $1.2 billion stadium, the Dallas Mavericks, the Dallas Stars, the Texas Rangers and the soccer team FC Dallas. Dallas's vibrant music scene covers the spectrum-rock, jazz, blues, country, classical and more. ,To get to all these venues, the University offers free DART (Dallas Area Rapid Transit) gold passes to students, giving unlimited access to buses, light rail and the University's own Comet Cruiser line that runs to local businesses and grocery stores near campus. ,The University of Texas at Dallas offers more than 130 academic programs across its seven schools. Undergraduate degrees include:,To help students with the transition to college life, UT Dallas offers two-day orientation programs that include the option to stay overnight in the Freshman Residence Hall. New students are advised on mastering their courses, meeting new friends and learning about advisors. Freshman Convocation, held the day before fall classes begin, provides an official welcome ceremony for all incoming students. ,The University offers a four-year comprehensive program for outstanding students, known as Collegium V. Collegium V includes special seminar-style classes offered by selected University professors as well as a program of extracurricular activities designed to encourage and reward exceptional academic achievement. Each of the University's seven schools also offers qualified students the opportunity to participate in an honors program within their discipline.,As a research-focused university, UT Dallas helps students seeking study abroad opportunities. Faculty and staff actively help students identify and apply for competitive programs with prestigious international universities. Students secure opportunities as varied as their interests. They have worked with an international research team in Ireland studying Lou Gehrig's disease, conducted a study on cognition and depression in Scotland, and collected public policy data in Zimbabwe. Faculty also lead travel study experiences, using the world as their classroom.,The Natural Science and Engineering Research Laboratory (NSERL) includes a nanoelectronics materials laboratory. The four-story, 192,000-square-foot, $85 million state-of-the-art facility draws faculty, graduate students and post-doctoral researchers from all disciplines around the world.,Students are able to work out on the latest equipment and participate in athletics and recreational sports. The University's Activity Center features a gym; racquetball, squash and basketball courts; a rock climbing wall; and a 25-yard indoor swimming pool. ,The Career Center offers a variety of services for students during all stages of their job search. Licensed professional career counselors provide career assessments and mock interview training. A full-time resume editor helps prepare resumes and cover letters, business communications and personal statements. The center also has career workshops and an online job-search database, and helps students find internships for the summer or school year. Because DFW is one of the nation's busiest and fastest growing business regions, UT Dallas graduates are highly recruited by leading local and national companies and receive prestigious graduate fellowships, scholarships and advanced research opportunities. Nearly all of the Fortune 500 companies headquartered in the DFW area recruit UT Dallas students. More than 84% of a recent UT Dallas graduating class reported employment or continuing education upon graduation. Recent graduates have received job offers from corporations that included Amazon, Citigroup, Exxon Mobil, Hewlett Packard, Merrill Lynch, Microsoft, Texas Instruments and Xerox.,The Student Success Center is part of the Office of Undergraduate Education and is a portal to educational enhancement and success. Our student success team members make every attempt to help students achieve their academic goals, whether it is through individualized tutoring, peer-led team learning, supplemental instruction or coordinated group study. Services include a math lab, writing center, and testing center. Success coaches help with time management, navigating the University and personalized plans for studying.,The Financial Aid Office awards scholarships to undergraduate and graduate students based on financial need, residency status and other criteria specific to the scholarship program. UT Dallas participates in all federal and state need-based financial aid programs, including grants, loans and work study.,All first-time college freshman undergraduates are considered for an Academic Excellence Scholarship Award, which range from $3,000 per semester up to complete coverage of tuition and fees.,The Guaranteed Tuition Plan is designed to help new students and their families better plan for the cost of a college education. It gives students a four-year, locked-in rate on up to 15 credit hours per semester.,The Tuition Promise dedicates resources to cover the tuition and mandatory fees for newly enrolling students whose families earn $25,000 or less annually and who meet other specific qualifications. ,Transfer students are considered for scholarship awards based on incoming transfer GPA and membership in organizations such as Phi Theta Kappa.,Scholarships offered through private sources are available throughout the academic year. Students apply for these types of scholarships through either a University scholarship committee or the specific donor.,McDermott Scholars, selected from top students across the country, have educational expenses - including tuition and fees, and stipends for living expenses, books, travel and post-graduation preparation - covered for four years. They also participate in a wide variety of cultural and educational enrichment experiences in the Dallas area and beyond.,Terry Scholars are Texas students nominated for their leadership potential and academic ability. The scholarships cover a broad range of student expenses over four years of study, including tuition and fees, housing, books and living expenses. Terry Scholars also have access to a broad range of academic, service, cultural, social and leadership opportunities intended to enhance their undergraduate experience.,Student organizations sponsor a variety of activities for the campus including service projects and community outreach. With more than 200 registered student organizations at UT Dallas, it is easy for students to get connected. UT Dallas is also home to 20 national Greek-letter fraternities and sororities, 13 competitive athletic teams, and 25 club sports. The School of Arts and Humanities presents an average of 50 artistic, musical and theatrical events a year. The UT Dallas chess team has won state, national and international titles and regularly represents the University in the Final Four of Chess.,Our students' ideas and visions for the University have become reality. From writing the alma mater and the fight song to founding the Greek System, the cheerleading squad, the Power Dancers and the student radio station, to helping design the freshman residence hall and campus dining facility, our students are making a difference.  ,To apply to UT Dallas, all students should submit an application for admission, which is available at ,. Applicants are required to submit official copies of all past academic transcripts, test scores and other degree specific documentation by the appropriate ,application deadlines to be considered for admission to The University of Texas at Dallas.,Official transcripts in envelopes sealed by the issuing institution may be delivered to the Office of Admission and Enrollment Services, or may be mailed directly from the educational institution. All materials submitted in the process of making application become the property of the University and will not be returned to the applicant.,Students in good standing from an accredited high school who have an SAT of 1200 (combined math and critical reading) or higher, a composite ACT score of 26 or greater or are in the top 15% of their high school class will be admitted to UT Dallas.,All fees are non-refundable.,Fall Full-Term                               July 1,Spring Full-Term                          November 1,Summer                                        April 1,All fees are non-refundable.,Fall Full-Term                              May 1*,Spring Full-Term                         September 1*,Summer                                       March 1*,Office of Admission and Enrollment Services ,The University of Texas at Dallas,800 West Campbell Road - ROC11,Richardson, Texas 75080-3021,Telephone: 00 + 1 + 972-883-2270,Fax: 00 + 1 + 972-883-2599 ,Email:

name: Victoria University of Wellington
textBelow: Entry is open to all at this 114-year-old university, but special selection criteria apply to the BA courses in criminology and creative writing, and candidates for the performance music programme must survive an audition. Victoria's 1,880-plus full-time-equivalent staff teach some 22,270 students, 4,200 of them postgraduates.

name: University of Tsukuba
textBelow: Tsukuba professor Shirakawa Hideki was joint winner of the 2000 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for discovering and developing conductive polymers. The school motto exhorts its students to "Imagine the Future", but its progenitor, the Tokyo University of Education, did so a good century before relocating to Tsukuba in 1973. Three clusters of 28 colleges were built within four years at the new location.

name: Tilburg University
textBelow: Tilburg has introduced "augmentation-reality" technology: point an iPhone at any campus building and the app supplies a pris of information about it, together with a promotional video about the university, home to 12,000 students and more than 1,300 faculty. Specialising in executive MBAs, the Faculty of Economy and Business Administration is its oldest and largest division.

name: Norwegian University of Science and Technology
textBelow: While specialising in science and engineering, NTNU also offers courses in social sciences and the humanities. Based in Trondheim, the Viking capital of Norway, it has seven campuses housing 53 departments in seven faculties, and 4,000 staff looking after some 20,000 students.

name: Wayne State University
textBelow: Wayne State gave several popular music performers their first public exposure: Alice Cooper, The White Stripes and Grand Funk Railroad, to name a few. Located in mid-town Detroit, this 143-year-old academy, with 2,700 faculty members overseeing around 32,000 students, runs more than 350 degree courses and claims to have 230,000 alumni worldwide.

name: Johannes Kepler Universität Linz
textBelow: The Harmony of the World was written by Kepler while living in Linz. The institution itself changed its name in 1975 when the city's earlier Academy for Social and Economic Sciences became a university. Its 90-acre out-of-town campus also offers law, sciences and engineering to some 13,700 students served by a faculty of 700.

name: University of Wollongong
textBelow: In less than 40 years the University of Wollongong has become a benchmark for Australia’s new generation of universities: dynamic, agile, innovative and prominent in national and international rankings for the quality of our research and teaching.,UOW routinely rates among the top Australian universities in key areas including teaching quality, graduate satisfaction and graduate starting salaries. Many of our researchers are leaders in their fields, nationally and internationally, while our research institutes have important global collaborative partnerships.,Our home is the coastal city of Wollongong—80km south of Sydney on Australia's east coast. We also have two campuses in Sydney, as well as four in the South Coast and Southern Highlands regions of the state of New South Wales.,With 24,400 students and 2,300 staff in Australia, our activities generate around $2 billion in economic activity annually, making UOW a major economic force in Wollongong and the wider region. UOW has been the catalyst for Wollongong's transformation into a university city with a clear focus on developing 21st century "knowledge economy" industries based on technology and innovation.,We also have a strong international focus with the flourishing University of Wollongong in Dubai celebrating its 20th anniversary in 2013, and a long history of successful off-shore course delivery in Singapore, Malaysia and Thailand. UOW also helped pioneer Study Abroad and Study Exchanges among Australian universities in the late 1980s, and now has partnerships with 230 universities in 42 countries, including 69 in the United States.,Our 112,000 alumni are making their mark on the world, from chief executives of global mining companies to senior government ministers and leaders in business, IT, engineering, the arts, science, medical science, law, education and much more.,To be a leader in ideas and solutions, a community of campuses and partners where discovery, learning and technology connect to transform people and the world we live in.,UOW's main Wollongong campus is set in native Australian bush and is widely regarded as one of the most picturesque university campuses in Australia. The campus caters for the vast majority of our 24,400 students and 2,300 staff. Apart from the extensive teaching and research buildings, our main campus includes student residences, conference facilities, food halls, cafes, restaurant and bar, conferences facilities, indoor sports centres and gymnasium, Olympic-standard swimming pool and sports fields.,UOW's , in Wollongong is a 33-hectare high-tech research and development precinct that allows innovative corporations from around the world to co-locate with some of UOW's leading research institutes in a collaborative campus environment. Leading companies such as global mining giant BHP Billiton, US IT company Commscope and Chinese IT provider Pactera are among the tenants at the Innovation Campus, alongside research institutes including the Intelligent Polymer Research Institute, the Institute for Superconducting and Electronic Materials, the Sustainable Buildings Research Institute and the Centre for Health Initiatives.,UOW has two campuses in Australia's largest city, Sydney, the capital of New South Wales and a leading financial centre for the Asia-Pacific region. UOW's Sydney Business School occupies three floors of an office tower at 1 Macquarie Place, Circular Quay, in the heart of Sydney's financial district, where it offers world-class business courses. UOW Southern Sydney at Loftus on the city's southern outskirts provides a range of courses for students living in the area.,UOW established the first of its satellite campuses in the Shoalhaven, 80km south of Wollongong, in 1993, so that residents of the area could benefit from a university education without the need to travel long distances or live away from home. Since then the network has been extended to include Batemans Bay and Bega on the NSW South Coast and Moss Vale in the Southern Highlands. Each centre offers a range of degree and diploma courses, with teaching on-site and via high-speed links with the main Wollongong campus, while the Shoalhaven Campus also includes a wing of our Graduate School of Medicine.,UOW established the , in 1993. From humble beginnings with a handful of students, it is now one of the most prestigious educational institutions in the United Arab Emirates. UOWD currently has around 3,650 students enrolled in undergraduate and postgraduate courses in Business, Finance, Computer Science, Engineering, International Studies and Media & Communications at its campus in Dubai's Knowledge Village.,Around 1,000 students are currently undertaking UOW courses in Malaysia under a partnership with leading South-east Asian education provider INTI International University and Colleges. UOW offers a Masters degree in International Business and Bachelor of Commerce, Bachelor of Computing Science, Bachelor of Information Technology and Bachelor of Media and Communications degrees at INTI's campuses in Kuala Lumpur and on the island of Penang.,UOW also has long-standing partnerships with two of Singapore's leading private colleges, the Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) and the PSB Academy, to deliver internationally-recognised academic programs in business, information technology and psychology.,We also deliver a Master of Education degree in Teaching English as a Second Language (TESOL) at Thailand's Assumption University in Bangkok, and a Bachelor of Nursing Conversion and Master of Nursing in partnership with IRI Hong Kong.,UOW has a number of national centres for research and training. These include:, is an international leader in applied infrastructure research and training, SMART undertakes interdisciplinary research to assist governments and business provide better infrastructure. It draws on UOW's proven inter-disciplinary research track record and its academic strength in the areas of engineering, commerce, informatics, law and science to holistically assess infrastructure solutions.,SMART's purpose-built headquarters on our main campus has sophisticated laboratories, teaching facilities and a simulation centre that allows its researchers to use a range of data sets, combined or in isolation, for infrastructure modelling and analysis.,The Australian Institute for Innovative Materials (AIIM) on UOW's Innovation Campus houses two of our research flagships, the Intelligent Polymer Research Institute (IPRI) incorporating the lead node for the Australian Research Council Centre of Excellence in Electomaterials Science (ACES), and the Institute for Superconducting and Electronic Materials (ISEM). AIIM's $50 million Processes and Devices Facility, opened in 2012, was built with assistance from a $43.8 million Australian Government grant.The building was designed to bridge the gap between research breakthroughs, prototyping and eventual commercialisation and sets a new standard for multi-functional materials research facilities in Australia.It is equipped to develop the new production processes, devices and prototypes that will enable research breakthroughs to be scaled-up for commercial application.,The AIIM facility also houses UOW's Electron Microscopy Centre, which contains seven highly sophisticated microscopy suites, two state-of-the-art preparation laboratories housing precision cutters, quality grinding and polishing tools, room temperature and cryogenic microtomes and highly accurate ion polishing systems. The facility caters for characterisation of materials including metals, ceramics, polymers and biological specimens.,The , is a collaborative venture between UOW and the Illawarra Shoalhaven Local Health District, dedicated to excellence and innovation in health and medical research that will lead to better health services in the region and the broader Australian community. Based at a $30 million research facility with purpose-built clinical trials facilities and sophisticated laboratories on the UOW campus, IHMRI was established to bring the University’s best health and medical researchers together with the region’s best clinicians. More than 100 scientists are now based at IHMRI with a further 180 using the facilities on a regular basis. name: University of Witwatersrand
textBelow: The University of Witwatersrand has a reputation built on research and academic excellence. It is one of only two universities in Africa rated by two separate international rankings as a leading world institution. It has grown from around 1,000 students to more than 28,000 by 2010. It boasts five faculties, comprising 34 schools. Witwatersrand is the recipient of the highest levels of external financial support of all South African universities.

name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
textBelow: Better known as Virginia Tech, this Appalachian academy is one of two American universities with a corps of cadets. The corps has nurtured seven Medal of Honor recipients: enrolling in it was compulsory until 1964. Erstwhile parade ground Drillfida is a large oval at the heart of the campus. It has more than 30,700 students and around 1,370 faculty members.
